Title: Proof that the trace of a matrix is the sum of its eigenvalues
Content: I have looked extensively for a proof on the internet but all of them were too obscure. I would appreciate if someone could lay out a simple proof for this important result. Thank you.
AcceptedAnswer:
These answers require way too much machinery. By definition, the characteristic polynomial of an $n\times n$ matrix $A$ is given by 
$$p(t) = \det(A-tI) = (-1)^n \big(t^n - (\text{tr} A) \,t^{n-1} + \dots + (-1)^n \det A\big)\,.$$
On the other hand, $p(t) = (-1)^n(t-\lambda_1)\dots (t-\lambda_n)$, where the $\lambda_j$ are the eigenvalues of $A$. So, comparing coefficients,  we have $\text{tr}A = \lambda_1 + \dots + \lambda_n$.

proof: Original problem: Prove that for a square matrix defined over an algebraically closed field, the trace of the matrix is equal to the sum of its eigenvalues.
Final Answer: Let A be an n x n square matrix over an algebraically closed field F. The eigenvalues of A, denoted λ₁, ..., λₙ, are the roots of the characteristic polynomial p(t) = det(A - tI). Since F is an algebraically closed field, the characteristic polynomial has exactly n roots in F (counting multiplicities). The expansion of the characteristic polynomial is given by p(t) = (-1)ⁿtⁿ + (-1)ⁿ⁻¹tr(A)tⁿ⁻¹ + ... + det(A). According to Vieta's formulas, the sum of the roots of a polynomial is the negative of the ratio of the coefficient of the tⁿ⁻¹ term to the coefficient of the tⁿ term. Applying this to p(t), the sum of the eigenvalues is: Σᵢλᵢ = -[(-1)ⁿ⁻¹tr(A)]/[(-1)ⁿ] = -[-tr(A)] = tr(A). Thus, the sum of the eigenvalues is equal to the trace of the matrix.
